emergencies.response: Your symptoms may indicate a medical emergency. Please seek immediate medical attention or call emergency services.
Heavy bleeding can be serious. Please consult a doctor or visit the nearest healthcare facility immediately.
Difficulty breathing is a medical emergency. Please call emergency services immediately (911) or go to the nearest emergency room.
Chest pain requires immediate medical attention. Please call emergency services or go to the nearest emergency room immediately.
If you suspect a heart attack, call emergency services immediately (911). Symptoms include chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, and pain in arms, back, neck, or jaw.
If you suspect a stroke, call emergency services immediately (911). Remember FAST: Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call 911.
If someone is unconscious, call emergency services immediately (911). Check for breathing and pulse, and be prepared to perform CPR if trained.
If someone is having a seizure, call emergency services (911). Keep them safe, don't restrain them, and time the seizure.
Drug overdose is a medical emergency. Call emergency services immediately (911) or contact Poison Control: 1-800-222-1222.
If you're having thoughts of suicide, please reach out for help immediately. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 988, Crisis Text Line: Text HOME to 741741, or call 911.
Please reach out for help immediately. You are not alone. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 988, Crisis Text Line: Text HOME to 741741, or call 911.
Please reach out for help immediately. Your life has value. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 988, Crisis Text Line: Text HOME to 741741, or call 911.
Please reach out for help immediately. You matter and help is available. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 988, Crisis Text Line: Text HOME to 741741, or call 911.
If you're in immediate danger, call 911. For support: National Domestic Violence Hotline: 1-800-799-7233. You deserve safety and support.
If you're experiencing abuse and in immediate danger, call 911. For support: National Domestic Violence Hotline: 1-800-799-7233, RAINN: 1-800-656-4673.
If you've experienced sexual assault, you're not alone. For immediate help: call 911. For support: RAINN National Sexual Assault Hotline: 1-800-656-4673.
If you've experienced sexual violence, support is available. For immediate help: call 911. For support: RAINN National Sexual Assault Hotline: 1-800-656-4673.
Severe allergic reactions can be life-threatening. If experiencing difficulty breathing, swelling, or severe hives, call emergency services immediately (911).
Anaphylaxis is a medical emergency. Use epinephrine if available and call emergency services immediately (911).
If you suspect poisoning, call Poison Control immediately: 1-800-222-1222, or emergency services (911) if the person is unconscious or having trouble breathing.
Severe burns require immediate medical attention. Cool the burn with cool water, don't use ice, and call emergency services (911) for large or deep burns.
If you suspect a broken bone, don't move the injured area, apply ice, and seek immediate medical attention or call emergency services.
Head injuries can be serious. If there's loss of consciousness, confusion, or severe headache, call emergency services immediately (911).
Concussions require medical evaluation. If there's loss of consciousness, vomiting, or severe confusion, call emergency services (911).
Severe dehydration can be dangerous. If experiencing dizziness, rapid heartbeat, or confusion, seek immediate medical attention.
Diabetic emergencies require immediate attention. If someone is unconscious or having severe symptoms, call emergency services (911).
Mental health crises are real emergencies. For immediate help: National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 988, Crisis Text Line: Text HOME to 741741, or call 911.
Severe panic attacks can feel overwhelming. If symptoms include chest pain or difficulty breathing, seek medical attention. For support: Crisis Text Line: Text HOME to 741741.
Eating disorder emergencies are serious. For immediate help: National Eating Disorders Association: 1-800-931-2237, or call 911 if in medical danger.

Mental Health Resources: National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 988, Crisis Text Line: Text HOME to 741741, SAMHSA National Helpline: 1-800-662-4357, Psychology Today therapist finder, or contact your local mental health services.

general_safety.response: Medication interactions can be dangerous. Always consult your pharmacist or healthcare provider before combining medications or supplements.
Many medications can affect pregnancy. Always consult your healthcare provider before taking any medication or supplement during pregnancy or while breastfeeding.
Taking too many supplements can be harmful. Follow dosage instructions and consult healthcare providers before taking multiple supplements.

Seek immediate medical attention for: severe chest pain, difficulty breathing, sudden severe headache, loss of consciousness, severe bleeding, signs of stroke (face drooping, arm weakness, speech difficulty), or severe allergic reactions.

disclaimer: Consult a doctor for medical advice. I provide educational information only and cannot replace professional medical care.
